KYC OBLIGATIONS

Table of Contents

Failing to take KYC measures

 

In a 2009 case, PayPal Australia breached the AML Act for failing to implement a satisfactory KYC mechanism for transactions under the $1000 threshold.

 

Following this breach, PayPal Australia agreed with AUSTRAC to address the deficiencies in its risk-assessment requirements. As part of this enforceable undertaking PayPal Australia sought to strengthen its risk-assessment systems and submit an independent expert report and remedy plan to AUSTRAC.

 

Reporting entities have customer due diligence (CDD) obligations. This involves:

 

•         collecting and verifying initial "know your customer" (KYC) information

•         providing ongoing monitoring of customers and their transactions

 

Taking KYC measures and collecting information about customers makes it much easier for your organisation to:

 

•         detect and deter money laundering and financing of terrorism

•         detect unusual or suspicious activity

•         avoid fraud or excessive risk in transactions involving customers

 

KYC measures enable reporting entities to effectively identify, verify and monitor customers and the financial transactions they are involved in, based on the risks of money laundering and financing of terrorism with those customers.

BE CAREFUL

 

Reporting entities must first carry out the relevant KYC procedures before it provides any designated services to a customer. Failure to do so can attract a penalty of up to $18 million for companies or up to $3.6 million for individuals.
